abstracts.cdata!:
Third Regional Development Project in
            West Africa achieved its objective of providing resources to
            a broad spectrum of viable investments projects. Although
            the overall program cost was in line with anticipation,
            project implementation took longer than initially expected,
            The Bank's response time to requests from the West
            African Development Bank (BOAD) regarding specific
            subprojects was too slow. BOAD development strategy did not
            provide a clear vision. The project objectives were vague,
            without a clear sense of priorities. No attempt was made to
            define indicators for assessing institutional growth. More
            importantly, the line of credit was extended at a time when
            the common currency of the sub-region was clearly
            misaligned, which created an unfavorable environment for
            private sector development. Overall, the outcome of the
            project is rated marginally satisfactory. No specific
            performance indicators were identified at the time of
            appraisal by which to measure the project's results
            but, the major benefits discussed in the Staff Appraisal
            Report (SAR) have been realized. In the context of policy
            framework coordination, the Bank team in charge of the
            proposed project should have included sector specialists, in
            addition to financial sector specialists.
